recordings.loc: Silver Creek, Cave Creek Canyon, Cochise County, Arizona
recordings.rmk: two birds in chasing flights giving steady quavering calls, going back and forth higher and higher up the opposite hill, then back down into the riparian closer to me; a third bird giving regular calls; these are wintering or migrating birds, hard to gather what was being contested, although perhaps a feeding territory involving acorns (which jays were busy gathering) or juniper berries (which solitaires were eating); loudest in the first 35 seconds and after 1:37; one whicker after 1:45;

recordings.loc: Silver Creek, Cave Creek Canyon, Cochise County, Arizona
recordings.rmk: aggregation of at least ten wintering or migrating birds, attracted by juniper berries and perhaps the acorns, to the dismay of the Acorn Woodpeckers; up to six in one tree at one point; some regular calls, and many interaction calls of whickers and the like, interacting with each other; partial annotations removed at 1:56 by 8 seconds and 4:38 by 16 seconds;

Santa Cruz Island, California
Sardis, Panola County, Mississippi
recordings.rmk:
Distance from microphone ~30 m. 60 F, calm. 

# Habitat #
Cypress Point, Sardis Lower Lake. Open hardwood grove along lakeshore.

# Editing #
Adobe Audition. FFT filter: Hamming window, 2048 pts, 400kHz-14kHz. 

# Equipment #
Fostex FR-2 digital field recorder with Telinga Pro 22" parabolic reflector

recordings.loc: Oxford, Lafayette County, Mississippi
recordings.rmk:
Distance from microphone ~50 m. 

# Habitat #
29-acre estate centrally located in Oxford, MS consisting of antebellum home surrounded by lawns and adjacent forest. Privet hedges and small thickets divide the grounds into distinct lawn units. Bordered on all sides by mature oak-hickory forest. Forest edge consists of oak spp, hickory spp, red cedar, mulberry, with understory along the edge dominated by privet (Ligustrum sp.). Grounds around the house include isolated trees and manicured hedges. A path from the end of the parking area leads northward ~1 km through the forest to the northern edge of the property abutting the University of Mississippi campus

# Editing #
Adobe Audition. FFT filter: Hamming window, 2048 pts, 1kHz-14kHz. 

# Equipment #
Fostex FR-2 digital field recorder with Telinga Pro 22" parabolic reflector

recordings.rmk:
Natural vocalizations by up to four northern flickers that were interacting at close range with three acorn woodpeckers in a dead tree.  

There was also an unidentified sparrow calling.

Habitat: chaparral recovering from a fire in 2009.  Scattered live and dead conifers and oaks.

Equipment: Olympus LS-10S, Telinga 22" paraboloid, Sennheiser ME62 microphone.

Modifications to the file: cropped at the beginning.  Low frequency noise filtered out.

recordings.loc: Mike's Sky Rancho, Sierra San Pedro Martir, Baja California
recordings.rmk: first whicker duet near the start was just before copulation; the pair has a hole in a short, broken-off, dead cottonwood, and the male spent much time working on that hole, with some regular calls and quiet 'werk' calls; f.k.a. C. a. martirensis; the drumming is all Nuttall's Woodpecker, the working is the flicker; interval shortened at 3:53 by 34 seconds;

recordings.file-name: XC540015-NOFI juvenile begging our feeders - Edited Copy.mp3
recordings.rmk: Recorded with Voice Record Pro on iPhone7, normalized to -3dB and converted to mp3.  Beginning and end trimmed to remove noises by the recordist but otherwise no modifications.  This juvenile flicker was constantly vocalizing while a male Northern Flicker (red-shafted with red malar stripes) fed at our suet feeders.  The sound would increase in volume and urgency when the juvenile was fed.

recordings.loc: Oxford, Lafayette County, Mississippi
recordings.rmk:
Foraging with other NOFL, a RBWO, and PIWO in a magnolia tree.

# Habitat #
29-acre estate centrally located in Oxford, MS consisting of antebellum home surrounded by lawns and adjacent forest. Privet hedges and small thickets divide the grounds into distinct lawn units. Bordered on all sides by mature oak-hickory forest. Forest edge consists of oak spp, hickory spp, red cedar, mulberry, with understory along the edge dominated by privet (Ligustrum sp.). Grounds around the house include isolated trees and manicured hedges. A path from the end of the parking area leads northward ~1 km through the forest to the northern edge of the property abutting the University of Mississippi campus. 

# Editing #
Audacity high-pass filter with 6 dB rolloff at 1 kHz.

recordings.loc: Four Mile Draw Rd, Custer State Park, South Dakota
recordings.rmk:
A bird drumming and calling from a trunk of dead ponderosa pine on a grassy hill next to a gravel road. Overcast, with light rain which can be heard hitting the microphone.

This area appears to have suffered a fire in recent years since all the trees in this area were dead trunks. As a result, this area held a large number of woodpeckers, including hairy, lewis's, red-headed, and northern flicker.

recordings.loc: Burrillville, Providence County, Rhode Island
recordings.rmk: Canon EOS Rebel T3i built-in mic. Habitat: Open, riparian freshwater marsh. Lots of tall dead trees. Grasses and reeds make up the undergrowth. Marsh surrounded by mixed coniferous forest. Behavior: Singing about 40 feet up in a dead tree. Adult male plumage. Conditions: Sunny, 80 degrees F, strong wind. Other: Recording was trimmed of extraneous noise, actual song frequency was about once every 60 seconds.

recordings.loc: Crest Trail, Chiricahua Mountains
recordings.rmk: initially three birds, one departing early on, after that two birds facing off from about a meter apart on adjacent side limbs, whickering periodically (very low gain) (more in the second half) D, motionless between whickers, but when vocalizing, spreading the tail, flicking the wings, moving the head from side to side; neither bird had a malar whisker, both perhaps hatch year; different than the group recorded earlier; I don't have any idea what this was about in early August;

recordings.loc: Florida Canyon, Pima County, Arizona
recordings.rmk: Filtered out wind sounds and background noise with WavePad. Vegetation is grassland with trees, near a riparian area (the creek that goes down Florida Canyon). I later heard what is probably the same bird, calling five notes in quick succession. It is known that there is a Golden Eagle staying in this area. I ruled out various hawks based on recordings here, and any other bird I could think of with a similar call.

recordings.loc: De Beque, Garfield County, Colorado
recordings.rmk:
Not sure what bird this song/call is. It's the faint trilling in the background that sounds similar to a loon call or an eastern gray tree frog (it's obviously neither of these, and the only amphibian species on this stretch is the tiger salamander, so I'm assuming this is a bird).

This bird was singing/calling within 100 meters of a creek, with the habitat being dry, with sagebrush and some trees in a higher-altitude section of western Colorado. It seemed to be singing from the sagebrush, but it was too overgrown for me to see the bird from the direction it was sounding off from. This was the only instance the trill was heard, and it only lasted for a few seconds. 

I was thinking of birds that could trill like this whose range overlapped where I am, and loggerhead shrike came to mind. The habitat would definitely support one, but again, not sure of the ID. Any ID help will be greatly appreciated.
